text: I do think team members should be playing to their strengths both Angelica and I are technical product managers so
hopefully we know a little bit about the technical side of things but really I do think the engineer should be owning the
technical side and the engineering decisions if we're rolling out something and there's some work that needs to be
done and is very engineering heavy then I fully put the responsibility on the team to let me know like we're going to
have to do this and then we're going to have to do that and then we're going to do this and then we'll be ready to launch and we'll want to plan the launch
in this way and do a gradual rooll whatever the case might be because the team ultimately has the ownership for
building a really high quality product or future or what have you the product manager should be doing the product work
helping make sure that we're launching well that we've given appropriate Communications to other teams or that
we've scoped what we're going to do ahead of time to give the context but there's definitely certain responsibilities that should be owned by
different individuals and what's really important is just to have good trust with each

I am joined by our wonderful panelist Chris so hello Chris hello happy that
you've joined for us for this conversation happy to be here how are you doing Angelica I am good I very

manager but I love Engineers I like to think of myself as a secret gopher so I
think this is going to be a good conversation for us to have so first of all I'm going to kick it over to you
Gail to explain to our lovely listeners who may not be aware what is a product
manager yeah thanks Angelica so a product manager in the definition I'd
like to give is somebody who identifies the customer need and blends that with
the larger business objectives to deliver a product that will be successful in the market that'll help
the company earn revenue and also they'll fulfill a need for our customers
and so product manager helps articulate a vision and rally a team towards that vision and make it a reality so I think
it's a very exciting role to have and how is it different from a project manager because I don't know whether
it's been your experience but in my experience when trying to talk to anyone about what I
do they default to oh okay you're you're project manager yeah yeah so project
manager oftentimes can work very closely with a product manager a project manager
will be a little bit more focused on planning or organizing and helping
direct the completion of a specific project so they'll help make sure that a project is on time or on on budget and
within scope they really kind of like try to help track down open questions and make sure everybody's aligned and
knows what's happening next and so they're really really focused on a project that's in progress getting that
executed and a product manager might be doing a couple different things like a product manager could be conducting
Discovery with customers like going out into the market observing how folks are using a product maybe they're doing
industry research and trying to figure out what a new product should be maybe they're doing some research and getting
feedback on existing product and what could be improved maybe they're doing some sort of strategy work uh trying to
think about how the company should be evolving and what does that mean for their product maybe they're helping the
engineering team think about tech debt and how we should be tackling that it could be a wide variety of things and
it's not always about executing a project that it's in F so tell me how
did you end up as a product manager yeah yeah well probably like many other
product managers it was by accident I had no idea that there was such a thing
as a career for product managers I've never heard of this so earlier on in my
life when I was in college I was really interested in public health and that led
me following College to work at a Community Development Bank so I was doing a fellowship where I was learning
more about the community what did it mean to do impact investing and how we could make loans to small
businesses in Chicago that's where I was located and I had the chance to have a
manager at the time during my fellowship who was giving me some feedback and one
day she said to me Gail I think you would be a great product manager and that you would really enjoy it I had no
idea what that was so she taught me a little bit about what it was and she explained how some of the work that I
had been doing was very similar to a product manager because I had been helping create new products for the
Community Development Bank and working really closely with customers and solving customer problems so she really
kind of opened my eyes to this potential career and then later on as I was trying to think about what to do as a next step
after the fellowship I found some product associate positions and I decided to give it a go and apply and
turns out I had a lot of good experience and that was it I just kept going
further and further into this career path so yeah just like somebody had heard about it and saw that I had like a
lot of the skills or like interests that mapped on well to doing a good job in this role and so they kind of like
pushed me towards it yeah for sure and I think it's interesting how so many of
the product managers that I've met have talked of this kind of falling into it
like they had no idea what it was then someone spoke to them about it and then they were like oh actually I'd be quite
good at this I love to hear from you Chris in terms of coming into the industry I
know we've talked about it before a little bit on the podcast but you came in quite senior so I really love to hear
a little bit about your experience getting to know you know how to work with product managers efficiently what
your experience has been and also maybe a little bit about the difference
between the various product managers you've worked with given that many of us have like completely different
backgrounds whereas as I'm generalizing here it seems that many software
Engineers know they want to do this very early it's a very kind of direct path to
a job as opposed to this kind of falling into it that certainly has been my
experience and Gail's experience I mean on your last point I mean I kind of fell into software engineering right like I
don't have a CS degree or anything like that but yeah I mean as coming into the industry as a pretty senior level person
I didn't actually work with a product manager until probably like 2 or 3 years
into my career there just like wasn't anybody that was kind of fulfilling that role in the places I was my first
experience with product managers were kind of like on the outskirts cuz I was like really working on internal stuff so there wasn't a lot of like you know
customer facing things I was doing so there weren't a lot of like interactions
I had with product managers but you know I like to hang out with them they were cool people I think the first time
actually like worked closely with the product manager though it wasn't too great of an experience I think it was mostly it seemed like they were a little
too much on the project management side it seemed like a lot of what they were doing was just very focused on like the
dayto day of what the engineers were doing and being like oh this is what I want you to do and not really like
getting us the information that we really needed about like what it is we were supposed to be building and I think
that's been a lot of my experience with product managers in general SP not
enough of like the really good ones that kind of go out and they're like okay here's all the information that you need
here's the requirements I've like thought through the things that we're going to try and build like here's the scope here's what you need to go do I've
often found that I have to do a lot of that work and a lot of the heavy lifting myself and then my team members who
don't do that heavy lifting wind up just not building the right thing at the end of the day and there's like features
missing or something got completely Mis scoped so like my overall experience has
has been quite Hit or Miss as far as product managers are concerned yeah this
interesting because I think when I first took some agile classes on how to be
part of a team and play the product role on the team like product owner role some of like the nitty-gritty details were
around like how do you write a ticket how do you manage the backlog for the team like you part of the team and
you're doing the backlog management but I think definitely as you start to level up as a product person you understand
that really what you're bringing to the table for the benefit of a team is doing
all of that really deep research of getting to know the space really well
and developing those relationships with the customers and even if it's an internal product perhaps your customers
are other teams internally and like asking the right questions to surface feedback from the teams and once you
have received that feedback kind of packaging it in a way that's really nice to bring back to your team and be like
hey here's what I'm here hearing here's what's working really well or here's where we could improve here's where I
see us going long term and then like getting feedback also from the team and like I think it's it really should be a
collaborative exercise as we're learning something to to decide okay where do we take this learning what's the next step
how do we keep improving but I I do think there's a little bit of an evolution that product people have to do is like first kind of get some of the
basics down and then like start to level up more and more and learn the really
key skills around doing the discovery work and the research and communicating
well and like asking really good questions that kind of get the nice medy information out of folks and then bring
that back to the team yeah for sure I mean Gail you talk about this collaboration between engineering and
product and Chris you've talked about the collaboration perhaps not so successfully but it's been a
collaboration I would love to hear from either of you what do you think makes a
successful partnership between product and Engineering sure I could take a first
crack at it I think when I reflect on Partnerships with engineering that I really enjoyed one it's been one where I
can ask stupid questions like well tell me a little bit about the architecture of the app like why is it that we need
to run this test why do we need to do this right now and you know having that space where I can feel comfortable and
then I can be taught you know this is why it really matters and then I can understand that okay this will make the
quality of the product much better and we should be prioritizing this right now being able to have that conversation
with the part my engineering Partners is really helpful and you know if somebody can explain something really well to me
uh that's valuable I appreciate diagrams diagrams are great anyone who draws a
diagram for me typically I will really like help me understand something and then I'm likely to be able to take that
information and then explain it to someone else so that's valuable to the team if I can go to another team and
explain like hey in this Sprint we need to be doing this and that but following Sprint we'll be able to work on the
deliverable that you need so you being able to learn from my engineering Partners works really well for me I
really enjoy being you know truly feeling like I'm a part of the team so I want to participate in retro and I want
to hear the hard feedback on how I can improve as a product manager and make things even better for the team like you
know maybe I didn't deliver a product requ requirement that was clear enough and it was blocking the team I want to
hear that and I'm really open to it so I I enjoy when I have that relationship with my engineering partners and then
you know I think sometimes I really appreciate having a partnership where we can be creative together so you know
maybe I'm trying to solve something and I'm not exactly sure what we could do but maybe we can bounce some crazy ideas
around together and we might find something that may not be the best solution but can get us to solve
something quickly and then we'll also talk about okay yeah that's fine for now but here's the other solution we would
prefer to do and I like having these conversations and you know not being the
only person that's throwing out crazy ideas and like hearing the pros and cons so yeah I like a really collaborative
relationship with my engineering Partners I think what comes to mind that
for me especially when you talked about like getting in a room brainstorming with your engineers do you need to have
software engineering expertise to be a good product manager I know we're going to talk a little bit about the
difference between technical to product manager and a product manager but in
general maybe I'll turn this to Chris do you expect your product manager to have
kind of technical skills if so to what level I'd love to hear a little bit about kind of your experience there and
your expectations from a product partner yeah so I think in general I
found that there's not really a clear line between like where things happen I
think it's like this kind of dance you have to do between like the product team and the engineering team to figure out
like where everybody is cuz I do think there are some teams of Engineers that are just like only care about like the
lowl technical stuff like don't really have that you know those that skill set in being able to like sus out like what
types of things do we need to add with the product and and figuring out all of the different edge cases and things like that so I think if there's like a team
that's like that then I think the product manager really does have to be like a technical person because they have to kind of descend down to that
level so they can communicate with them and if you have someone that's not technical but with a team that's super technical I think there's there's a lot
of struggles that happen and especially around communication especially around like prioritizing things and backlogs
and and stuff like that I am kind of on the other side of things when it comes to being an engineer like I'm very good
at thinking about like edge cases and like what we need for like what we would want to have in our product and like I'm
capable of sitting down and talking to customers and talking to clients whatever and kind of assessing what we
need from there and extrapolating so I think for me I definitely prefer product managers who can focus Less on the
technical stuff and more on those like higher level requirements people that can like answer questions that I'm not
capable of answering myself and I kind of feel like that's how we should be building engineering organizations I
think it's not really that great to try and have someone that's not very close to the code and working with the code
all of the time trying to make decisions about what we should do with the code or how we should prioritize things with a
code so I think it's like our our Engineers should kind of level up a bit more to the product people in soad the
product people having to come down so I also think if the product people have to come down then it's like well who's going to do the other stuff the product
people need to be doing we can't just be like oh well you just have all of this extra work to do now because you know
our Engineers don't want to figure out how to like assess product you know requirements and translate them into
actual things that we can go out and build but I think that also has implication unlik who owns what I think
one of my I guess interesting opinions is I don't think product managers should own backlogs I think in general that's
like the the place of the team more than anything else the team should own their backlog and should kind of prioritize it
and they should have input from the product manager but I think giving that away to someone else takes away some of
the autonomy of a team this especially true if like the product organization feels further away from the engineering
organization as a whole that is very interesting opinion I actually like building off of
that I think I had a situation where I had to step away from the team for a little bit so it was less involved and
the team very much was operating without a product manager and I think one of the things that worked really well for the
team is having context like the team knew what was the goals for the team what was the vision what we were trying
to accomplish and from then on really the engineers could be self-directed in determining all right we need to have
these stories this Sprint and it would really ideal if we finish these Milestones within this time frame and I
didn't really have to be you know like a hawk over the backlog and like moving things around or up and down to
different sprints on the other hand I think the backlog is a good tool for a product manager when you're having
conversations with other teams like that's where it's really helpful because you can kind of keep an eye on if there
was a request from another team you have an understanding of all right it's not going to go into this Sprint because
we'd have to drop something else but it's likely to go into the next Sprint so I can reasonably Say it'll be done
around this time frame and that helps build really strong Partnerships with other teams and then you can help kind
of like move projects along if you ever have an eat from another team like building that relationship and enabling
teams to work really well together that's really key to delivering features in a successful way especially if it's
like a really complex project that has dependencies on many teams aligning all the depend icies can get tricky so I
think for the product manager that's where the backlog and kind of keeping an eye on where things go becomes a really
useful tool and I think too part of the problem is like the the tooling we have
is pretty awful for most of this like I think any of the you know task SL isue
managers Jiro what have you they don't really have enough of the utilities you need especially for complex projects
that's something I've always found failing in the past if but there is something that we're trying to do across multiple teams trying to visualize and
track that especially at a like not fine grain someone will go do this individual unit of work but in this like here's a
thing that we need to do when we want to track it it's there's a lot of work that you have to do to actually put all of
that together or to assemble that even within a system as powerful as jira and I think that also like not having a
separate view of the tasks that need to get done I think gravitates people
toward just like piling everything into the backlog and like this is a source of Truth and then you have like different
things that are supposed to be owned in there and it's like not clear who owns what and there's not a good way for to say a less technical person to like be
able to prioritize things in there that's always been my problem with some you know product managers is when you know they kind of go to the backlog and
they start rearranging the things that they want and they just like shove down all of the dependencies and it's like we
can't do that and it's like arguably our tooling should prevent that from being a problem it should prevent you from
putting things out of order but that's really hard to do with the tooling that exists now yeah something you said
earlier really spoke to me which is I do think team members should be playing to their strengths so I know Angelica
mentioned both Angelica and I are technical product managers so hopefully we know a little bit about the technical
side of things but really I do think the engineer should be owning the the technical side and the engineering
decisions if we're rolling out something and there's some work that needs to be done and it's very engineering heavy
then I fully put the responsib ility on the team to let me know like you know we're going to have to do this and then we're going to have to do that and then
we're going to do this and then we'll be ready to launch and know we'll want to plan the launch in this way and do a
gradual roll out whatever the case might be and you know because I think the team ultimately has the ownership for
building a really high quality product or feature or what have you so I think
it's more on that the product manager should be doing the product work helping make sure that we're launching well that
we've given appropriate Communications to other teams teams or that we've scoped the what we're going to do ahead
of time to give the context but there's definitely like certain responsibilities that should be owned by different
individuals and what's really important is just to have good trust with each other like if I know that you are
working on engineering piece of it then you know it's that's your responsibility
and my responsibility is to support from the product perspective and so I guess to go back to the backlog management
definitely there's more like engineering heavy ticket it's you know my Approach as a product person is always just to
ask the team like hey you know what's the how high priority is this should I keep it towards the top you know when do
you want to be working on it what is it going to enable us to do and you know just enough questions to be able to pull
it into the Sprint or not depending on what the team [Music] [Applause]

Time how would you feel Chris about a product manager who was very technical
maybe was a previously a software engineer and did understand everything
about the system was able to review PRS was able to really get down in the weeds
and therefore could go through all the tickets in the backlog could even create all the technical tickets and then
perhaps it would come to you or the team and be like okay this is the technical approach we're taking here are the
tickets Please execute that for me I'm obviously being
very kind of I would do this but to get that conversation going that for me even
saying it now I know a lot of people who wouldn't be happy with that yeah at that
point you're not really doing that's not really product management anymore right that's like Team Management to some
degree right you're the one that's like setting up all of the work for everybody to do and I would assume also like
tracking to make sure that people are doing things so that's like team plus project management which is not what product management is about but I think
that's where you know there's roles you have to fill on every team right like every team obviously needs Engineers but you also need someone to like be the the
leader of the team so that we can get consensus around everything that you're doing you need someone to keep track of
whatever is going on to make sure that you know things aren't you know getting lost you have to have someone that is
out there like setting the future saying hey this is where we want to go like these are the things we want to build so
you can have you know one person that fulfills those things you can have a couple people that kind of shift between those things but I think it's very
important to like actually make the roles very clearly defined as to like what they are and what they expect
because I think like part of the problem we have probably as an industry is that we're very bad at defining what these roles are
which I think explains why we have so many of these like titles that all have the same letters in them like there's
product manager project manager technical project manager technical product manager it's like all of these
things it's like they're all kind of operating in the same space we're trying to use like one thing to describe it's like okay no you're like you're doing
some project management you're doing some product management and like that's okay one person can do both those things but we should call it like that cuz I
think when you when you don't do that then it makes it hard for people to I think a switch between teams or move around teams and we around companies but
it also just makes it very unclear when you start to scale how you actually scale the team right because then if
your team gets you know that might work for one product manager when you have you know a team of five people but if
you have a team of 10 or 15 people that's a whole lot more work to do for
one person now you're like okay we need to bring a second person in finding someone that can do that mix of product
and project management work is going to be really difficult to do and if you've already defined up front you're like okay well these are my project
management responsibilities these are my product management responsibilities and you're like okay now it seems like there's more project management that has
to get done so we'll hire another project manager and I can still do product and some of the project stuff
right so you can start like kind of dividing things out a little bit better but yeah I think for me personally I
would not want to be on a team where a product manager is that heavily involved in the backlog and that heavily involved
in in the process I typically don't like team teams where the engineers don't
have a high degree of autonomy and a high degree of trust in them so I think ultimately the way I kind of see things
is like Engineers should be trusted to prioritize work properly they should be trusted to you know maintain the backlog
because at the end of the day it's like if you have a bunch of tickets and let's say that you wrote them all up well the
engine have to understand them so it's like now you have to spend all this time translating it for them it's easier if they just write them themselves make
sure they have the information so another team member could actually pick up that ticket do it and they have to
own the responsibility of making sure that that information is sufficient for what other people need so higher-ups
need to be able to track what's going on the tickets need to have enough information to make that happen I think that's much more scalable than trying to
put that all onto one person and I've definitely seen it more scalable in teams like that I think a lot of the teams I've been on there's just been
like one person that's trying to like write up all of the tickets or like the team manager like get takes the Epic and
then breaks it out into a bunch of stories and then like all all in this like under this I think thought process
that like oh well we just want the engineers to be like writing code and I think that that doesn't help us in the
long run it's like engineering is about more than just writing code I think in the last podcast I said like writing code is the least important part of
software engineering there's so many other things that we have to do and if you don't give the engineers the
autonomy to do that if you don't give them the authority to do that then they're going to just you know not do it
and that's going to make it much more difficult to build software in the end so I think in general it's a long way of saying I product managers need to be
much higher up than that I don't think that they should really be doing that project management work and I don't think you should necessarily bring on a
project manager until it's like okay no we really have a team big enough that we need someone to like manage everything
because it's difficult for engineers to keep on top of all of it so you would not be happy if I jumped on a PR and
reviewed it I mean like you could but I don't know if that's like the best use of a that's like half PM half software
engineer which once again if that's like a thing we have then like sure but from like a this person is a product that is
their title that is all they do I'd be like no that person's like a product manager plus some level of engineer
because that's what they're doing and we should call them that and then yeah sure like 50% product 50% engineer cool that
I don't have a problem with that yeah I think like if the product manager were that Hands-On you would probably not be
spending your time on other things that to me are the more fun things that are part of the role but on the other hand
like maybe I don't know maybe your product is a product that is for other engineers at the company and you're
trying to understand like what is the experience and so maybe that's why you're doing a PR to experience it
yourself you know maybe in that case it's it's appropriate but yeah I think I
would strike a balance like I think the engineers should be able to write their own tickets and determine what's
important to work on next and product person should also be writing some tickets everybody on the team who
identifies a need for something that the team should be working on should be able to write a ticket
and yeah I think we should all be expecting that things can change with you know something happens maybe there's
an incident or some new customer need or business has shifted in a dramatic way
maybe due to the pandemic or something else we might need to be regenerating our backlog and so yeah I think that's a
collaborative exercise and I don't think it has to all be done by the product manager I think the product manager can
help shape maybe some of the practices like you know for example one of the things I like to help make
sure we're doing just for good team health is to be really clear on the acceptance criteria so we can all agree
like okay this work is done here's the scope of it you know so that we can keep delivering so like that's one of my
things I like to make sure we have acceptance criteria and that we all understand what the acceptance criteria
are I don't like to be prescriptive about like how we're going to do something especially not on the
engineering side I think that is Way Beyond what I should be doing and that would not be
appropriate so I know we've touched on this a little bit and it's been mentioned a few times in regard to
external team management and dependencies so a lot of our time as product managers is spent having
meetings with people understanding their needs understanding what work is required from our team I guess do we
either Gail or Chris see a world in which a senior software engineer a
engineering league would take on that role if we got rid of the PM role within
a team or do you feel like product managers have unique skill sets and this
is not a trick question to be able to do that just because I know Chris you've talked about that being something you'd
like you know the engineers to be thinking around business value being able to prioritize their work so I'd
love to hear your views on that yeah I I think it depends on what the team is
doing so I think if it's like internal products versus external products I think in some cases depending on the
size of the company an internal product manager makes sense but I think for most companies you probably want the
engineers to kind of be doing their own product and be be able capable of doing that sort of work but I think in general
like the thing that I've always found is like if you have good process for your organization as a whole and you have
good form of communication like the need to have a human that's kind of
transiting information between people decreases a lot so I think like I mean I always see as kind of a failing of an
organization even when like a manager has to talk to another manager to Transit some information because then
you're going from like some engineer to telling some manager telling another manager telling an engineer and it's like we all play telephone as a kid that
never worked well it was always like you know that was the fun of the game is you'd be like oh what weird thing is
going to come out the other end of the telephone line that's completely not what I said so I think fixing those
problems and reducing the friction of communication is super important there and I think that can actually reduce the
need for like as many like internal or cross team product managers and then I think you know product managers really
do get to go talk to the people who like aren't within the company and aren't going to adhere to the same sort of process and communication systems or
like you know just aren't going to be able to give that feedback like if you are just building a product and you have like some us like actually sit down talk
